example: print(map.remove("nope")) // 0 (fail, as this key does not exist)
map.remove(map.indexOf([3,4,5])) //remove an item from map by its value
remove.description: Remove an item from a map, by its key (`string` or `int`). Returns `1` (true) or `0` (false).

example: print(map.push("k")) // push also returns the map object
map["l"] = 12; //alternative to push, allowing us to declare the value
push.description: Pushes a new key (`string` or `number`) onto the end of map, with value of `1`. Returns the updated `map` object.

pop.description: Returns the key (`string` or `int`) of the first element in the map, and removes that element from the map.

shuffle.description: Randomly remaps values in a map, leaving the keys in their original order. Returns `null`.

example: map.sum // 2 (2 is the only sole integer value in our example map)
sum.description: Returns the total (`int`) of all numeric values in the map. This applies to `numbers` only and excludes strings, lists and maps within the map.

hasIndex.description: Does map.key exist? The key may be a string or integer. Returns `1` (true) or `0` (false).

indexOf.description: Get the index (in maps, this will be the key) of a value. Optionally searches after begin (`any` key). Returns key (`string` or `int`) or `null` (key/value not found).

example: print(map.indexes[2]) //error: using a list in this way requires a reference
list = map.indexes //instantiates the list to this variable
indexes.description: Returns a `list object` containing all the map keys.

len.description: Returns the length of the map (`int`).

values.description: Returns a `list` containing all the values within the map.
